content:
Kinda cool: https://css-tricks.com/houdini-how/

https://houdini.how/

Houdini.how | CSS-Tricks
Nice site from Google (and guest contributors) with a bunch of fun demos of what Houdini can do. Plus a write-up from Una. These are all Paint API demos.
Cool indeed :smile:
Ping @indigoxela since this is in your wheelhouse

Wow. I find this exciting, but mostly terrifying:

https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2016/05/houdini

So, powerful new abilities...but even more things you need to master in order to build powerful, useful, and attractive websites?

Houdini: Demystifying CSS  |  Web  |  Google Developers
Houdini is a collection of APIs that expose the CSS engine’s internals to developers

@Luke McCormick (cellear) fortunately, if you know CSS, this is something that a lot of non-programmers can easily get behind to create some crazy powerful effects. I like the idea that all you need is to 1) add a link to the library and 2) learn some new CSS selectors.

It never occurred to me that "the web" could totally create their own selectors to do things that aren't part of the "standard". I'm sure it's already been a thing, but this is the first I've run across it.

That sounds promising, the way you describe it. There’s always a battle between increased power and increased complexity. In the 35 years that I’ve been paying attention, I’ve seen it break in either direction numerous times. Getting it “right” is really hard, but not impossible.

Yeah, I see it as a way for CSS to finally begin pushing forward by the community instead of having to wait for a handful of people to argue and decide on what they think we all need. Now if we can just get the browsers to start allowing us to easily override form elements without a bunch of hacky CSS...
Looks like a bunch of stuff added to Chrome engine but not Firefox or Safari

@Herb I was under the impression that because of how it pulls in the Backend stuff, it works with FF and safari

Ah, looks like you're right: https://houdini.how/about

Still, fun stuff. To clear up any confusion, I wasn't saying we should add this to BD. I wasn't sure which stream to add it to and thought a general CSS topic might be beneficial for generic discussion about CSS down the road.

I wasn't sure which stream to add it to...

Probably Community Chat.
This topic was moved here from #Backdrop > CSS by klonos

So much for a general CSS topic for BD :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:

No worries, we probably need the same topic for both streams.
:smile: I prefer specific topics more.

This was fun. Never knew you could "chain" shadows.

YouTube - YouTube

CSS loading animation

https://dev.to/xinnks/make-animated-content-placeholders-with-html-and-css-3ekn

Make Animated Content Placeholders with HTML and CSS
A brief tutorial on how to create animated content placeholders with HTML and CSS.
Hmm, not sure I like the semi-flashing animation...
It's for the idea, maybe not so much the practicality of it.

CSS accessibility ideas: https://css-tricks.com/beautiful-accessibility-with-floating-focus/

Beautiful accessibility with Floating Focus | CSS-Tricks
Imagine if your :focus styles animated from element to element as you tab through a site. Like the focus ring up and flew across the page to the next
Yeah, I can see the benefit of that @Phil Ward :+1:
